Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of Primary Cilia by Ceramide

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit
The primary cilium is an "hair-like" structure protruding from most mammalian cells and cells of many other metazoans. It serves as a sensor for growth factors and mechanical impacts. Like an antenna or GPS, it helps motile cells locate the source of these signals and move toward or away from them. This function in cell migration is critical for closing wounds or forming tissue layers during embryo development. In many non-motile cells, specialized primary cilia are important for sensing light, odorants, or fluid shear stress. The current project will determine how the formation of primary cilia is regulated, which is important to understand its function.

The P.I.'s group is interested in the regulation of the primary cilium by lipids. Lipids are fat-soluble components of the cell membrane. The P.I. has found that one of these lipids, ceramide, is particularly important for the protrusion of the membrane when the cilium is formed. Ceramide is incorporated into a complex with proteins, which drives the formation of the primary cilium. The P.I.'s research project will determine how ceramide is generated and which ceramide-protein complexes are important for cilium formation and function.

Broader impact
The results from this project will open a novel field in the biological function of lipid cell signaling and will advance our knowledge across different fields. This project will foster the academic career of at least two graduate students and encourage the enrollment of minority students from a partnering community college into the PhD program of the P.I.'s institution. The P.I. collaborates with a local painter to visualize science through art, which is an exciting avenue to ignite the interest of the public in scientific education and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project determines an evolutionarily conserved mechanism by which a fat-like substance or lipid (ceramide) in the cell membrane regulates primary cilia. Primary cilia are protrusions of the cytoskeleton and cell membrane that work like antenna sensing growth factors and mechanical impact in the outside environment of the cell. They are critical for growth factor-regulated tissue development and measuring fluid flow in the kidney and other organs such as the brain. The P.I.’s laboratory has discovered that the lipid ceramide is critical for the function of primary cilia and differentiation of neural stem cells in brain development. The P.I.’s research has determined the mechanism by which ceramide regulates primary cilia and their function in stem cells. Essential part of this project is the inclusion of graduate and undergraduate students and their education. This education has been extended to elementary, middle, and high school level students in innovative workshops combining art and science (“Living clay” workshops and lectures at local high schools).

 

Specific outcomes:

1. The number and length of primary cilia is regulated by ceramide. The P.I. has determined that a particular enzyme, neutral sphingomyelinase 2 (nSMase2), generates ceramide in specific vesicles at the base of primary cilia. When ceramide is generated, it is transported to the ciliary membrane (a part of the cell membrane that forms the cilium protrusion) and promotes cilium length extension. The P.I. has also determined that ceramide stabilizes cilia by activating enzymes that increase resistance of the cytoskeleton inside of cilia to mechanical impacts.   

 

2. The P.I. discovered that the mechanism by which ceramide stabilizes cilia is already active in green algae (Chamydomonas). In addition, he found that this mechanism stabilizes the cytoskeleton in protrusions of nerve cells (neurons), which is vital for establishing neuronal connections in the brain. Therefore, ceramide-dependent regulation of cilia and other cellular protrusions is an evolutionarily conserved mechanism important for many different developmental processes and brain function.

 

3. The project has fostered the accomplishment of the thesis work of two graduate students. It also supported the education of eight undergraduate students and two high school students in the P.I.’s laboratory. Of specific mention is the outreach activity of the P.I. by establishing a collaboration with a local potter to organize art-science workshop (“Living Clay” workshops) for elementary and middle school students. In the “Living Clay” workshops, students use clay to sculpt cells and cellular organelles, which is complemented by courses on the evolution of cell protrusions and organelles as biological tools.

 

The accomplished project has formed the basis for continuation funding on further understanding the mechanism(s) by which ceramide regulates cilia. Of particular interest of the continuation project are motile cilia, which are also cell protrusions, but drive the flow of extracellular fluids.
